aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Analysis - Apopka, Florida (October 24, 2019)
The accident occurred in Apopka, Florida.
The accident occurred on October 24, 2019, at 09:30 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a COSTRUZIONI AERONAUTICHE TECNA P2004.
The aircraft registration was N639BV.
The defining event of the accident was a hard landing.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Instructional.
The solo student pilot was not injured in the accident.
The solo student pilot reported the aircraft was 5 to 10 knots faster than normal during landing.
The solo student pilot reported there was little to no flare during landing.
The aircraft touched down hard on the runway.
The aircraft bounced after the hard touchdown.
The aircraft nosed over after bouncing.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the left wing.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the vertical stabilizer.
The solo student pilot reported no preaccident mechanical failures with the aircraft.
The solo student pilot reported no preaccident mechanical malfunctions with the aircraft that would have precluded normal operation.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the student pilot's improper landing flare.
The improper landing flare resulted in a hard, bounced landing.
The hard, bounced landing resulted in a subsequent nose-over.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Aircraft control - Student/instructed pilot" as a personnel issue finding.
The National Transportation Safety Board identified "Landing flare - Not attained/maintained" as an aircraft finding.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Apopka, Florida

## Date & Time: 
October 24, 2019, 09:30 Local

## Registration:
N639BV

## Aircraft:
COSTRUZIONI AERONAUTICHE TECNA P2004

## Defining Event:
Hard landing

## Injuries:
1 None

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Instructional

## Analysis

The solo student pilot reported that, while conducting a touch-and-go landing, the airplane was 5 to 10 knots faster than normal during the landing and had little to no flare. The airplane touched down hard on the runway, bounced, and nosed over. The airplane sustained substantial damage to the left wing and vertical stabilizer. The student reported that there were no preaccident mechanical failures or malfunctions with the airplane that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
The student pilot's improper landing flare, which resulted in a hard, bounced landing and subsequent nose-over.

## Findings

| | |
|-|-|
| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Student/instructed pilot |
| Aircraft | Landing flare - Not attained/maintained |

---
